item.title: Entropia on Kickstarter
item.description:
• 2-6 players
  • Teams mode
  • 54 cards with multiple choices
  • Paper game
  • Print'n Play version
  • Kickstarter ends soon!

In Entropia, a young star is born and chases its destiny among the suns and planets of the galaxy. Ending on Kickstarter this week, Entropia is a fresh card game with familiar mechanics and a friendly price.

Back Entropia for a print-n-play version, or get the Premium edition, delivered in a quality metal box.

Jump to the special card reveal!

A star is born

Each player is a young star that is trying to form their very own planetary system in which to reside. The first person to control five planers wins the round, and the first player to reach 3 rounds wins.

The game is rather small, at 54 cards total. But stategy is key — as each card can be used in different ways:

  • you can keep the planet
  • or you can discard and choose an effect on play
  • and you can create combos

Other players will try to steal or even destroy your planets, so you'll need to get creative fast. Different actions and ways to combo ensure play variety, but also enable one strategy or another.

Who should play?

I find it's a great intro to more serious card games, because it has familiar concepts from other popular card games like Hearthstone or Magic.

The cards allow you to draw & discard, build a board state or attack an opponent, do combos and tempo swings. (yes, we're card nerds here!)

As you can see, you can have events like "When you attract a planet", which you can manipulate with another card — you'll be pondering this play .

Game modes

The game can be played with 2 to 6 players, although it's best when 4 people duke it out. There's also a Teams mode with 2v2 or 2v2v2, each team with their own mechanics and team strategies.

What sounds really good for a game this size is the upcoming Big Bad Boss Battle mode which pits 2-3 players against 1 powerful star. This is reminiscent of Magic's Archenemy format, which I've always wanted to try, but never did it, since it requires special cards and rules. This game mode is still in testing and will be released as a free rule-book.

Special reveal

We also have a surprise for existing and future backers! Two new cards have been revealed. The first one highlights the choice aspect, present on a lot of cards.

The second reveal is a little more cryptic! It's an unstable planet — can't wait to find out what this does!

item.title: Shadowverse Next shakes up the game
item.description:
Shadowverse is a manga-style digital CCG available on mobile and Steam. The game took the world by storm, counting over 14 million downloads.

  • Set Rotation!
  • New class: Portalcraft
  • All changes December 28
  • Plus a new set!
  • In-game Tournaments in 2018

Big news this week for Shadowverse players: developer CyGames showcased their set of announcements, dubbed "Shadowverse Next", which are bound to shake up the game in December.

Shadowverse is gearing up for it's 7th set and with it, we'll see some major changes to game modes, as well as a whole new class.

More on Shadowverse and other games in our latest issue »

New class: Portalcraft

Yuwan and the all-new Portalcraft class will arrive on December 28. Yuwan is a vengeful warrior who has the power to traverse dimensions, and will fight alongside Arisa and the others to save the world.

The core class mechanic is Resonate — cards with Resonate can activate special abilities and effects when there is an even number of cards in your deck.

Right alongside that are Artifact cards – token cards you can add either to your deck, or to your hand, so you can more easily activate Resonate cards.


Rotation and Unlimited

With the release of the 7th Shadowverse set in December, you'll be able to play in two game modes: Rotation and Unlimited.

Rotation will only allow decks made with cards from the latest 5 sets, as well as most Basic cards. This is an idea often found in popular games such as Magic: the Gathering or Hearthstone. Once the new set is out, Shadowverse will have over 1000 cards. The Set Rotation will keep the meta fresh, and make the game friendlier for new players.

The Rotation format will always feature only the latest 5 sets.


If you're attached to your collection, don't fret! Unlimited mode will allow all cards in the game. This is OK in theory, as it doesn't alienate veteran players, because it provides a game mode which rewards them for their knowledge of the game. However, what happens in other card games is that this "full" mode becomes a fringe area of the game, as most players tend to focus on the newest cards. I guess we'll have to wait and see how it plays out in Shadowverse.

You'll also like our intro article to MTG: Arena — coming 2018

Tournament mode

Finally, Shadowverse will include an automated tournament mode, a feature sorely missing from other competitive card games.

Tournaments are coming in 2018. "This will be an in-game tournament that anyone can join, regardless of rank. There will be preliminaries matches to determine which players make it to the finals to earn exclusive rewards."

item.title: MTG Arena Developer Q&A
item.description:
MTG: Arena is a new digital CCG in Wizard's Magic: the Gathering family. We're covering all the latest updates in our Arena series.

Jump to: Cards - Beta info - Timeline - FAQs

  • Best of 1 Ladder in November Beta
  • Best of 3 + sideboard is next
  • Closed beta is Under NDA until 2018
  • PC Only for now
  • Sign up for the Beta here

The MTG: Arena team held a Q&A session on Twitch about the upcoming beta. Nate sat down with Executive Producer Chris Cao to talk about the Beta schedule and what's coming early 2018.

The beta invites started going out this week, and people started playing, but we won't see any streaming any time soon. They will open tests during the weekend, until they can reach 24/7 playability around November 30th.

The Ladder and Sideboards

They confirmed the Ladder will be 1v1, single-game matches, or Best of 3 + Sideboard. You will be able to choose which Ladder you want.

Free-to-play

The team re-iterated their commitment to free-to-play. They want to make sure you'll be able to build a collection and play Ladder in a purely free-to-play fashion.

Cards and sets

Most cards from the Standard sets are already working, as far as rules are concerned, but they are missing design assets, such as animations and interactions. This is actually why we'll have to wait a bit more for another set.

Draft

They have been testing 8-player drafts, and this game mode will be available in the Closed Beta. There is no timeline for it at the moment.


Beta schedule

They are starting with a Stress test on November 3rd, and add more play days in the following weekends. You'll be able to select one of a few pre-made decks and battle it out with other players. We expect the decks to be similar to the ones showcased so far, like the above U/R Sorcery played at the community deck showdown.

After that they'll expand the beta and release more features. This will happen before the end of November.

Beta NDA and feedback

The invite emails will contain clear instructions about the NDA and what you need to do to be able to play.

The basic rules: don't post anything publicly on social media or other outlets. This means no screenshots, videos, streaming or tweets.

You will be able to download a special installer, which will get the rest of the game. As far as feedback is concerned, you'll receive instructions on how to provide it. The whole idea is not to post anything publicly while the game is under NDA.

There's loads more to come on MTG: Arena.

item.title: MTG: Arena Questions answered
item.description:
MTG: Arena is an upcoming free-to-play digital CCG in Wizard's Magic: the Gathering family.

  • Closed beta starts in November
  • All cards from Ixalan set
  • All Standard sets at launch
  • Focused on 1v1 battles
  • PC Only for now
  • Launches in 2018

Fun times ahead: MTG Arena starts closed beta soon, and this means we get more info about the game. Follow along as we try to answer all your questions about gameplay details, cards and sets, game types and more.

Also see our intro article to MTG: Arena

Closed Beta players won't be allowed to stream yet, but the devs are very active in the community. There's a great lineup of events leading up to the launch, so check back often for updates.

Where can I play?

MTG Arena will be PC only in the beta, because the devs need to iterate fast. They've built the game on a flexible engine, so they can easily expand to other platforms when it's ready. So this probably means mobile clients will be next.

Is this real MTG?

Short answer: YES! The beta will have the full Ixalan set. See our article for more details on what this means exactly.

So will it have trading?

Well, no. There's no trading involved. Arena is a free-to-play game where you gradually grow your card collection from packs. You can also buy packs for real money to unlock cards faster.


Does it replace Magic Online?

No. Arena will be a new game, focusing on Standard and Limited play (Drafting, or like Hearthstone's Arena). If you want to trade, or play with older Magic sets, Magic Online is the place for you.

Does it replace Duels?

No. This is an entirely new game. Duels was a watered-down version, focused on single-player and casual play. Magic will cater to this audience, but will also be perfect for pro-level play, streaming and eSports.

Will it have vanity items?

Yes. They want feedback from the community about what should be customizable.

What about foil cards? That's an obvious ask isn't it?

Very much so! But the devs haven't shared anything on this yet!

They want you to play with the Standard decks from any Pro Tour.


How do I get a Tier 1 deck?

The team is focused on allowing players to easily build their collection, up to a Tier 1 deck. They want you to have the Standard decks that you see in a Pro Tour.

How many creatures can be on the board at a time?

There was mention of a playtest game with 200 creatures at once (tokens) so that's the real Magic right there!

Any crazy digital-only modes?

There was a question about game modes unique to Arena as a digital game. They are not working on it — in fact, they're only thinking about it because the community mentioned it. This really hints at the fact that they are fully committed to replicating Magic precisely, and don't want to stray from the true Magic feel.

There's loads more to come on MTG: Arena.

item.title: Magic the Gathering: Arena
item.description:
MTG: Arena is a new digital CCG in Wizard's Magic: the Gathering family. Here's all the info we have on the launch, cards and sets, game types, FAQs and more.

Jump to: Cards - Beta info - Timeline - FAQs

  • Closed beta starts in November
  • PC Only for now
  • Launches in 2018
  • All cards from Ixalan set
  • All Standard sets at launch
  • Focused on 1v1 battles

Hearthstone took the world by storm and gave new life to what seemed to be an established genre. The past few years saw a ton of big releases in the digital CCG genre, from new players such as Eternal, Shadowverse or Gwent, as well as big franchises such as Elder Scrolls: Legends.

Now it's time for the big one. The one that started it all. Magic is finally entering the modern digital era.

MTG: Arena is a fresh entry in a long-running franchise, and it's the first title in a new Digital initiative from publisher Wizards of the Coast. It's a Free-to-Play digital CCG where you battle it out online with the newest Magic cards and planeswalkers.

Magic old and new

Magic was already playable online — Magic Online first launched in 2002 and it's exactly like the tabletop version, trading included. But Arena is fully embracing the new digital landscape: built for quick play, with a ton of eye-candy for streaming, catering to both casual players and the eSports crowd, it promises an experience on par with other modern CCGs.

If you're new to Magic, then watch this space: Arena shapes up to be a great intro to this vast world.

Gameplay

In many aspects, Arena is very much like Hearthstone and similar games: you build decks from a collection, get packs with real money or by just playing the game, and then duke it out in casual or competitive modes. There's promise of Draft gameplay as well as single-player content, but that's after Launch, sometime in 2018.

Arena will have all cards from the tabletop set, and it will receive new cards at the same time with regular Magic releases. Right now, this means 4 sets per year with a total of over 1000 cards! Yes, that's a lot, but you should know what you're getting into!

The beta will be PC only, but they're already thinking on how to bring it to mobile platforms.

Show me the cards already!

MTG: Arena will start Beta with all cards from the newest Magic set, Ixalan.

The four peoples of Ixalan are locked in a deadly struggle as they search for the golden city of Orazca.

The set features Pirates, Vampires, Merfolk, Dinosaurs, and 3 powerful planeswalkers.

Ixalan also has double-faced cards: special Artifact and Enchantment cards which Transform into powerful Lands once certain conditions are met.

sound good?

Check out the full Ixalan card list

I know Magic — what should I expect?

People familiar with Magic gameplay will soon realize that Magic is far more complex than Hearthstone or other digital CCGs out there. Wizards has built a new Rules Engine just for this game. Supposedly, the rules engine can handle everything they throw at it, and can even figure out most new cards on its own. Now that's forward-thinking!

This means that we will get full Magic, and not some watered-down version, like Duels. They have gone on record saying that you can totally build a pro-tour level deck, or that they've played a game with over 200 creatures on board (mostly tokens, but still impressive).

Combine this with the fact that they'll have all Standard cards at launch, plus Draft mode, and potential tie-ins to the tabletop game and events like Friday Night Magic, and you get actual, real MTG. Can't wait!

How will Magic happen?

Just as you'd expect, you can manually tap for mana, tap cards, select attackers and blockers, get a chance to respond with Instants and abilities. You can also go on autopilot, and have the game do some of these things for you. The new Rules Engine is so smart that it can figure out when it needs to ping you for an action.

A good example is Priest of the wakening sun : every turn, you may reveal a Dinosaur card to gain 2 life. If you don't have a Dinosaur in your hand, the game won't ask you.

When can I play?

The closed beta will start in November. Go to PlayMTGArena.com and sign up.

Here's what you need to know:

  • There's no tutorial in the beta — you need to know the rules
  • You'll be under NDA - cannot stream, write, or publicly talk about Arena
  • Accounts will be wiped at the end
  • It's PC only

There is a priority access queue for people who played tabletop or MODO during the Ixalan release, as well as for people who played Duels. Read more here

What's next

The MTG: Arena team is gearing up for the Closed Beta with a series of streams in October and November, in which they talk more about the game.

See the updated stream list here.

There's loads more to come on MTG: Arena.

item.title: A guide to Elder Scrolls: Legends for Hearthstone players
item.description:
original article by /u/Karandor

Do you need a break from Hearthstone? Is the SmOrC too much? Does the Lich King put you off with his icy puns?

Then look no further than The Elder Scrolls: Legends, the CCG set in the popular TES universe. The new Skyrim expansion is out and the skies are full of dragons, so there's no better time to join the fray!

This guide will get you started in no time. Since you're familiar with Hearthstone, we'll skip the beginner stuff and dive right into the most important details: main concepts, keywords, classes, crafting, game types and decks to play.

Quick jumps:

  • Basics
  • Runes & Prophecy
  • Lanes

Pro tip: You can bookmark this page and come back to it for the quick reference cards.

What's cool about TES:Legends?

Right off the bat, Legends has a more serious tone than Hearthstone. If you love the high-stakes approach of Skyrim, you'll feel right at home. The single-player content is grim, there's a somber atmosphere, and dragons! Of course, the gameplay is still fun and has it's glorious moments — you'll have plenty of laughs in Skyrim.

Gameplay

The basic gameplay of Legends is identical to Hearthstone. The decks are bigger, but you still draw 3 cards with a mulligan, and you take turns playing creatures and spells. Your mana increases with 1 each turn. There's a ring — just like The Coin — and you get to use it 3 times (once per turn). You target the same way. There is no blocking phase and the only creatures that can keep you from hitting face have Guard (Taunt from Hearthstone).

Players start with 30 health. There are actions and abilities that restore health, and there is no maximum health*: you can gain life over the starting 30.

* Actually, there is - it's 999 (same as any max stat, it seems). It doesn't have any practical relevance other than for the record's sake though.

Combat Lanes

The big difference in gameplay comes from the board. There are 2 lanes in Legends and creatures cannot attack between lanes. However, most abilities can be used anywhere.

The 2 lanes are not equal: creatures summoned in the Shadow Lane (the right-hand lane) have Hearthstone Stealth: they cannot be attacked for 1 turn after they are summoned. But unlike Stealth in Hearthstone, they can still be targeted by actions or summon abilities.

The idea of 2 lanes plus the Shadow Lane will make most players sick with the idea of unchecked aggro. This is where the second big change to gameplay comes in: runes.

Prophecy runes

You start the game with 5 runes, which break at 25, 20, 15, 10 and 5 health. When your health reaches one of these runes the rune breaks and you draw a card. Runes don’t regenerate.

The really interesting part is that there are Prophecy cards that can be played for free when you draw them off of a rune break. This mechanic changes the SMOrc meta considerably and you have to be careful about playing around runes.

Runes are also relevant in fatigue: if you run out of cards and draw dead, it breaks one of your runes. If you have no runes left, you die. Due to the decks being 50 cards, this happens less often than Hearthstone.

Basics
You get 30 life, 3 cards (4 if you go second) and you can mulligan once.
Decks are 50 cards, with cards of 1 or 2 colors + neutrals.
Runes
Runes break at or below 25, 20, 15, 10, 5 health. A rune draws a card for you or your opponent. If the card has Prophecy it can be played right away, for free.
Be careful to play around runes: sometimes it's good not to attack.
Lanes
You play minions in 2 lanes. The right lane is the Shadow Lane: creatures played there can't be attacked for one turn, but they can be targeted with spells.

Keywords

Most keywords in Legends should be familiar to you:

  • Ward = Divine Shield
  • Guard = Taunt
  • Lethal = Poison
  • Charge = Charge
  • Last Gasp = Deathrattle
  • Silence = Silence (it’s rare, just as in HS)
  • Slay = When this minion kills another minion.
  • Shackle = Freeze
  • Pilfer = Triggers when the minion deals damage to the face
  • Regenerate creatures have all health restored at the start of your turn. This works like Stoneskin Gargoyle
Summon = like Battlecry

Summon triggers when a card gets into play. It's usually present on creatures, but it can also be found on some Items. There's a big difference from Hearthstone: while Battlecry triggers when you play the card, Summon also triggers when a card is put into play by effects. Therefore, stuff like clone or revive effects are much more powerful in Legends. Summon can also target itself, so if a creature gives +1/+1 on Summon, it can give it to itself. Battlecry doesn't work like that at all!

Drain = Lifesteal

Damage dealt also heals you for the same amount. Three things you need to know about Drain.

  • Ward blocks all Drain as it counts as 0 damage.
  • Drain creatures always drain their power value whether or not the creature you hit had that many HP. So if you hit a 2 HP creature with a 6 power drain you will heal for 6.
  • drain creatures only drain on your turn!

    • Breakthrough

    Breakthrough is the same as trample from MTG but is missing from HS. It means that when the creature trades, any damage it can do over the current health of its target will hit face. So if you hit a 1 health enemy with a 4 power breakthrough creature it will kill the enemy creature with 1 health and do 3 damage to face.

    Cards and decks

    Legends has colours instead of classes. The rarities of cards are the same: common, rare, epic and legendary. One difference is that not all legendaries are unique: you can have up to 3 of some legendaries in a deck.

    Types of cards

    Legends has spells (Actions), minions (creatures) and weapons (Items), just like Hearthstone.

    In addition, there are Support cards, which stay in play, and can be removed only with special Actions (much like Enchantments in Magic). And Item cards — magic objects or weapons you can equip on your creatures (like in Magic).

    Heroes of Skyrim contains five Shouts (one in each attribute), which are Actions that get stronger with each use. Shouts start each game at level 1, and after you play a Shout all of your copies of it upgrade to the next level (maxing out at level 3). As Shouts level up, their magicka costs stay the same but their effects get much more powerful.

    One more thing to mention is that board clears in Legends are much more rare than in Hearthstone. Creatures may look underpowered, but the board is generally much more sticky than in Hearthstone, so minions can still be incredibly effective. However, single-target removal is still pretty powerful, so be warned!

    Deck construction

    Any deck can use cards from 2 colours as well as from the neutral card pool. You can also make single colour decks or even full neutral decks but you can't use more than 2 colours. The game has class names for all the 2 colour combinations:

    • Red-blue: Battlemage
    • Red-yellow: Crusader
    • Red-green: Archer
    • Red-purple: Warrior
    • Blue-yellow: Mage
    • Blue-green: Assassin
    • Blue-purple: Sorcerer
    • Yellow-green: Monk
    • Yellow-Purple: Spellsword
    • Purple-green: Scout

    Most cards have one colour. There are a few dual colour cards for every class.

    What you see with this is that good cards get spread around to a lot more decks and the meta is generally more mutable. It also allows for creativity in deck construction.

    Decks are 50 cards. Other than specific Unique Legendaries, you can have up to 3 of any card in your deck. Legends-decks.com is the best resource for finding deck ideas but you can often personalise or come up with decks that can be successful outside the established decks.

    Those are the differences between Legends and Hearthstone. Now go forth and plunder!

    Stay tuned for Part 2: What decks to play!

item.title: Welcome to Frivolity
item.description:
If you’re a fan of card games, you probably heard of Card City Nights by now. Released back in 2014, the quirky card game was a mash-up featuring characters from Ludosity’s other games, reimagined as card players. With an interesting core mechanic, stellar soundtrack and spiffy characters, the game was well-received and still provides a refreshing experience 3 years later. So naturally, fans are eagerly awaiting the sequel!

The upcoming Card City Nights 2 launches September 1 on Steam. The game is familiar, yet new, with 200+ cards and some big changes to core mechanics. And, what's even more exciting, it brings a much-awaited feature: online multiplayer.

Players will place cards on the same game board.

CCN 2 combines traditional deck-building and card battle gameplay with a RPG-like story-line. You’re traveling aboard Starship Frivolity, where everyone’s favourite pastime is - you guessed it - playing cards! You battle zany characters in a quest to achieve fortune & glory. Oh, and collect all the cards! Then, you duke it out online with other players.

The core gameplay features an unique card chaining mechanic. Players seek to activate cards by linking their chain points. Once you link 3 cards, they resolve. When a card is resolved, it may trigger abilities, and then it leaves play.

That sounds simple, but it gets a lot more complex once you start playing. Factors such as card placement, timings, chain points and card abilities ensure a variety of tactics. The game promises a diverse metagame, close to the traditional aggro-combo-control scale of other CCGs.

The Potato — #1 card in the beta

Developers Ludosity are tiny but strong: while just a small team of 6, they've been around for almost 10 years, and have over 20 published titles. They all feature an unique feel, "lighthearted and funny with a cartoony style".

The team had a blast balancing the meta in their first multiplayer beta, which ended a few weeks ago. So I asked Joel Nyström to take a little time and give us some insight around the game, the beta and what to expect in multiplayer come September.

  1. Vlad: So Card City Nights 2 is out in September, excited about that?
  2. Joel: Yes, very excited! The reception so far has been very good, and we have a lot more stuff to reveal yet =)
  3. Vlad: Will we play a much different game at launch, than now in the beta?
  4. Joel: The multiplayer matches will not change significantly from what you saw in the beta, except for improved menus and UX. However there's also the whole single-player adventure that we haven't revealed yet!
  5. V: Multiplayer is very much anticipated, at least judging from the player activity in the beta. What were the challenges to create a multiplayer component to Card City Nights?
  6. J: The original CCN was probably not very balanced for competitive play, I think some cards were simply just better than others in that game. Because it was only a single-player adventure, we balanced it according to a difficulty curve that fit with the story arch. With CCN2 we try to balance the cards so that there will be no dominant strategies and every card can fill a useful role in a deck.
  7. V: We definitely saw better balance in the mp beta. Speaking of, was there a meta-game already forming?
  8. J: The community would often post on the forums what decks/strategies they perceived as dominant, but the dominant strategies changed several times over a short 10-day period, and looking at the stats, the numbers aren't quite showing the same picture! So balancing the meta is something that's going extremely interesting once the game is live.
  9. V: How different is it to test it with real players, versus just an internal test group? Was there a lot of unexpected stuff happening?
  10. J: We did the beta precisely to be on stand-by to quickly fix as many things as we could during the 10-day beta. It was a lot of fun, and very intense! Working live against an audience is a blast!
  11. V: Any critical balance changes that you've identified in the beta?
  12. J: Yes, in the initial version we might have gone a little too far with the unusual and weird mechanics, while neglecting the core mechanic of connecting chains. This was re-balanced during the beta.
  13. V: Will we see some single-player content closer to launch?
  14. J: There won't be any more betas before launch now, but we'll start revealing more of the adventure in trailers, screenshots and blog-posts soon! Also, catch us at Gamescom in Cologne this August and I'll personally show you =)

With all that in mind, multiplayer should be a total blast! The last beta gave us a taste. Focused on multiplayer, beta #2 was open to 1000 players, who quickly generated a meta that shifted quite a bit during the course of the event. As a result, the devs released a couple of balance changes in short succession.

Princess Remedy proved to be a great control card

I loved the fact that new decks emerged every day: at first, the Frog deck ruled. Then, players started countering it with control decks, then by using the best princess there is: Princess Remedy . In the last few days, people noticed that a fatigue archetype is a contender for "top deck". This can only mean good news for the finished game — everyone wants a dynamic meta with multiple deck types to explore.

Card City Nights comes out on September 1 on Steam.
